group that follows the [[Wahhabi]] doctrine of [[Sunni Islam]]. It is based in and around [[Jolo]] and [[Basilan]] islands in the southwestern part of the [[Philippines]], where for more than four decades, [[Moro people|Moro]] groups have been engaged in an [[insurgency]] seeking to make the province independent. The group is considered violent{{cite web|last1=Feldman|first1=Jack|title=Abu Sayyaf|url=http://csis.org/files/publication/111128_Fellman_ASG_AQAMCaseStudy5.pdf|publisher=Center for Strategic and International Studies|accessdate=16 May 2015}} and was responsible for the [[Philippines]]' worst terrorist attack, the [[2004 SuperFerry 14 bombing|bombing of Superferry 14 in 2004]], which killed 116 people. The name of the group is derived from the Arabic ''[[Abu (Arabic term)|abu]]'' ({{lang-ar|أبو}}) ("father of"), and ''sayyaf'' ({{lang-ar|سيّاف}}) ("swordsmith").[https://www.fbi.gov/pressrel/pressrel06/mostwantedterrorists022406.htm FBI Updates Most Wanted Terrorists and Seeking Information – War on Terrorism Lists], ''FBI national Press Release'', 24 February 2006 {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100830144046/https://www.fbi.gov/pressrel/pressrel06/mostwantedterrorists022406.htm |date=30 August 2010}} As of 2012, the group was estimated to have between 200 and 400 members, down from 1,250 in 2000.{{cite book|last1=East|first1=Robert|title=Terror Truncated: The Decline of the Abu Sayyaf Group from the Crucial Year 2002|date=2013|publisher=Cambridge Scholars Publishing|page=3|url={{google books |plainurl=y |id=pzgyBwAAQBAJ|page=2}}|accessdate=17 May 2015|isbn=9781443866699}} They use mostly [[improvised explosive device]]s, mortars and automatic rifles. Since its inception in 1989, the group has carried out [[bombing]]s, [[kidnapping]]s, assassinations and [[extortion]].{{Cite journal|last=Rommel C. The group was founded by [[Abdurajak Abubakar Janjalani]], and led after his death in 1998 by his younger brother [[Khadaffy Janjalani]] until his death in 2006. On 23 July 2014, Abu Sayyaf leader [[Isnilon Hapilon]] swore an [[Bay'ah|oath of loyalty]] to [[Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi]], the leader of [[Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant|ISIL]].{{cite web|url=http://www.rappler.com/nation/65199-abu-sayyaf-leader-oath-isis|title=Senior Abu Sayyaf leader swears oath to ISIS|work=Rappler|accessdate=18 July 2015}} In September 2014, the group began kidnapping people for ransom, in the name of ISIL.{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/sep/24/islamists-philippines-threaten-kill-german-hostages-isis|title=Islamists in Philippines threaten to kill German hostages|author=Philip Oltermann|newspaper=The Guardian|accessdate=18 July 2015|date=24 September 2014}}{{cite news|last1=Sherwell|first1=Philip|title=How Abu Sayyaf makes a business of beheadings as Islamist terror gang releases 'final message' hostage video|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2016/05/20/how-abu-sayyaf-the-islamist-terror-gang-made-a-business-out-of-b/|accessdate=14 June 2016|newspaper=The Telegraph|date=23 May 2016}} {{toclimit|3}} ==Background and history== In the early 1970s, the [[Moro National Liberation Front]] (MNLF) was the main Muslim rebel group fighting in Basilan and Mindanao. [[Abdurajik Abubakar Janjalani]], the older brother of [[Khadaffy Janjalani]], had been a teacher from Basilan, who studied Islamic theology and [[Arabic]] in Libya, [[Syria]] and [[Saudi Arabia]] during the 1980s.{{cite web|title=Abu Sayyaf History |publisher=U.S. Pacific Command |date=21 September 2006 |url=http://www.pacom.mil/piupdates/abusayyafhist.shtml |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090123213349/http://www.pacom.mil/piupdates/abusayyafhist.shtml |archivedate=23 January 2009}}{{cite news|title=Who are the Abu Sayyaf |date=30 December 2000 |publisher=BBC |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/asia-pacific/719623.stm |location=London}} Abdurajik went to Afghanistan to fight against the [[Soviet Union]] and the Afghan government during the [[Soviet–Afghan War]]. During that period, he is alleged to have met [[Osama Bin Laden]] and been given $6 million to establish a more Islamic group drawn from the MNLF.{{cite web |title=Funding Terrorism in Southeast Asia: The Financial Network of Al Qaeda and Jemaah Islamiyah |url=http://www.nbr.org/publications/analysis/pdf/vol14no5.pdf |publisher=The National Bureau of Asian Research |accessdate=20 September 2006 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060927184541/http://www.nbr.org/publications/analysis/pdf/vol14no5.pdf |archivedate=27 September 2006 |url-status=dead }} The [[Autonomous Region in Muslim Mindanao]] (ARMM) was established in 1989 in part in response. Both Abdurajik Abubakar and Khadaffy were natives of [[Isabela, Basilan|Isabela City]], one of the poorest [[cities of the Philippines]]. Located on the northwestern part of Basilan, Isabela is the capital of the province. Isabela City is administered under the [[Zamboanga Peninsula]] political region north of Basilan, while the rest of the island province of Basilan is since 1996 governed as part of ARMM to the east.{{cite book |last1=Banlaoi |first1=Rommel |title=Al-Harakatul Al-Islamiyyah: Essays on the Abu Sayyaf Group, Terrorism in the Philippines from Al A Qaeda to ISIS |url=https://www.academia.edu/40446207 |website=Academia |publisher=Philippine Institute for Peace, Violence and Terrorism Research |accessdate=5 October 2019}} ===Abdurajik Abubakar Janjalani leadership (1989–1998)=== In the early 1990s, MNLF moderated into an established political government, the ARMM. It was established in 1989, fully institutionalized by 1996, and became the ruling government in southern Mindanao. When Abdurajik returned to Basilan island in 1990, he gathered radical members of the old MNLF who wanted to resume armed struggle and in 1991 established the Abu Sayyaf. Janjalani was fundedby a Saudi Islamist, [[Mohammed Jamal Khalifa]], who came to the Philippines in 1987 or 1988 and was head of the Philippine branch of the [[International Islamic Relief Organization]] foundation. A defector from Abu Sayyaf told Filipino authorities, "The IIRO was behind the construction of Mosques, school buildings, and other livelihood projects" but only "in areas penetrated, highly influenced and controlled by the Abu Sayyaf". According to the defector, "Only 10 to 30% of the foreign funding goes to the legitimate relief and livelihood projects and the rest go to terrorist operations".Zachary Abuza, "[https://www.jstor.org/stable/25798639 Funding Terrorism in Southeast Asia: The Financial Network of Al Qaeda and Jemaah Islamiyah]," ''The National Bureau of Asian Research'' 14, no. 5 (December 2003): 176. {{cite web |title=National Commission on Terrorist Attacks upon the United States |url=http://govinfo.library.unt.edu/911/archive/hearing3/9-11Commission_Hearing_2003-07-09.htm |accessdate=19 June 2012 |date=9 July 2003 |quote=MR. GUNARATNA: Sir, Mohammad Jamal Khalifa ... arrived in the Philippines in 1988 and he became the first director, the founding director, of the International Islamic Relief Organization of Saudi Arabia.}}{{cite book|last1=Giraldo|first1=Jeanne K.|last2=Trinkunas|first2=Harold A.|title=Terrorism Financing and State Responses: A Comparative Perspective|publisher=Sanford University Press|page=120|url={{google books |plainurl=y |id=BOfC7vJOsdIC|page=120}}|accessdate=13 May 2015}}{{cite web|title=Complete 911 Timeline. Mohammed Jamal Khalifa|url=http://www.historycommons.org/timeline.jsp?other_al-qaeda_operatives=complete_911_timeline_mohammed_jamal_khalifa&timeline=complete_911_timeline|website=History Commons|accessdate=13 May 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150518092750/http://www.historycommons.org/timeline.jsp?other_al-qaeda_operatives=complete_911_timeline_mohammed_jamal_khalifa&timeline=complete_911_timeline|archive-date=18 May 2015|url-status=dead}} Khalifa married a local woman, Alice "Jameelah" Yabo. {{cite book |last=Abuza |first=Zachary |title=Balik-Terrorism: The Return of the Abu Sayyaf |publisher=Strategic Studies Institute, US Army War College |location=Carlisle PA |isbn=978-1-58487-208-5 |url=http://www.strategicstudiesinstitute.army.mil/pdffiles/pub625.pdf |page=47 |date=September 2005 |accessdate=19 June 2012 |quote=Based on IIRO documents at the PSEC, Khalifa was one of five incorporators who signed the documents of registration; another was Khalifa's wife, Alice 'Jameelah' Yabo.}} By 1995, Abu Sayyaf was active in large-scale bombings and attacks. The first attack was the assault on the town of [[Ipil, Zamboanga Sibugay|Ipil]] in [[Mindanao]] in April 1995. This year marked the escape of 20-year-old Khadaffy Janjalani from [[Camp Crame]] in [[Manila]] along with another member named Jovenal Bruno. On 18 December 1998, Abdurajik was killed in a gun battle with the [[Philippine National Police]] on Basilan Island. He is thought to have been about 39. The death of Aburajik marked a turning point in Abu Sayyaf operations. The group shifted to kidnappings, murders and robberies, under younger brother Khadaffy. Basilan, Jolo and Sulu experienced some of the fiercest fights between government troops and Abu Sayyaf through the early 1990s. Abu Sayyaf primarily operates in the southern Philippines with members traveling to [[Manila]] and other provinces. It was reported that Abu Sayyaf began expanding into neighboring [[Malaysia]] and [[Indonesia]] by the early 1990s. Abu Sayyaf is one of the smallest, but strongest of the Philippine [[Islamist]] separatist groups. Some Abu Sayyaf members studied or worked in [[Saudi Arabia]] and developed ties to [[mujahadeen]], while fighting and training in the war against the [[Soviet invasion of Afghanistan]]. Abu Sayyaf proclaimed themselves to be [[mujahideen]] and freedom fighters. ===Khadaffy Janjalani leadership (1999–2007)=== Until his death in a gun battle on 4 September 2006, [[Khadaffy Janjalani|Khaddafy Janjalani]] was considered the nominal leader of the group by the [[Armed Forces of the Philippines]]. Then 23-year-old Khadaffy took leadership of one of the Abu Sayyaf's factions in an internecine struggle.{{cite news|title=Fresh fighting in S Philippines |publisher=BBC |date=7 September 2006 |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/asia-pacific/5322680.stm | location=London}} He then worked to consolidate his leadership, causing the group to appear inactive for a period. After his leadership was secured, Abu Sayyaf began a new strategy, taking hostages. The group's motive for kidnapping became more financial than religious during this period, according to locals. The hostage money probably provides the group's financing. [[File:Jainal Antel Sali, Jr.jpg|thumb|left|Photograph of [[Jainal Antel Sali Jr.]] in 2006. Sali was later killed during a heavy gunfight with the Philippine authorities in 2007.{{cite web|url=https://news.yahoo.com/s/ap/20070117/ap_on_re_as/philippines_abu_sayyaf|title=Philippines says militant's death a blow|author=Jim Gomez|agency=Associated Press|publisher=Yahoo! News|date=17 January 2007|accessdate=17 October 2017|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070118204619/http://news.yahoo.com/s/ap/20070117/ap_on_re_as/philippines_abu_sayyaf|archivedate=18 January 2007|url-status=dead}}]] Abu Sayyaf expanded its operations to Malaysia in 2000, when it abducted foreigners from two resorts. This action was condemned by most Islamic leaders. It was responsible for the kidnapping and murder of more than 30 foreigners and Christian clerics and workers, including Martin and [[Gracia Burnham]].{{cite news|title=Manilla captures senior Abu Sayyaf|publisher=CNN|date=7 December 2003|url=http://www.cnn.com/2003/WORLD/asiapcf/southeast/12/07/philippines.abusayyaf/index.html}}{{cite news|title=Ex-hostage describes jungle ordeal|publisher=CNN|date=9 May 2003|url=http://www.cnn.com/2003/US/05/08/cnna.burnham/index.html}} An influential commander named [[Abu Sabaya]] was killed at sea in June 2002 while trying to evade local forces.{{cite web|title=Prominent Abu Sayyaf Commander Believed Dead|url=http://www.ict.org.il/spotlight/det.cfm?id=796 |publisher=Institute for Counter-Terrorism|accessdate=20 September 2006|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060105081224/http://www.ict.org.il/spotlight/det.cfm?id=796 |archivedate=5 January 2006}} His death is considered a crucial turning point for the group, as the number of operatives working for Abu Sayyaf sharply decreased from 1100 in 2001 to 450 in late 2002, and had since been stagnant for the next ten years.{{cite book|last=East|first=Bob|authorlink=Bob East|title=Terror Truncated: The Decline of the Abu Sayyaf Group from the Crucial Year 2002|date=2013|publisher=Cambridge Scholars Publishing|location=[[Newcastle upon Tyne]], United Kingdom|isbn=978-1-4438-4461-1|url=https://books.google.com.ph/books?id=pzgyBwAAQBAJ|accessdate=3 December 2019|pages=3, 23}} Galib Andang, one of the group's leaders, was captured in [[Sulu]] in December 2003.{{cite news|title=Profiles of dead Abu Sayyaf leaders |publisher=BBC |date=15 March 2005 |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/asia-pacific/4350033.stm |location=London}}{{cite news|title=Bloody end to Manila jail break |publisher=BBC |date=15 March 2005 |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/asia-pacific/4349471.stm |location=London}} An explosion at a military base in Jolo, on 18 February 2006 was blamed on the group by Brig. The plot was reported to have involved detonating a car bomb in [[Cebu City]] where the summit was to take place.{{cite news|title=Manila Again Denies Terror Plot Led to Postponement of Asia Summits |date=13 December 2006 |publisher=Voice of America (VoA) |url=http://voanews.com/english/2006-12-13-voa11.cfm |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://archive.today/20061213232350/http://voanews.com/english/2006-12-13-voa11.cfm?renderforprint=1&textonly=1&&CFID=40218514&CFTOKEN=43906189 |archivedate=13 December 2006 |accessdate=12 December 2016}} On 27 December, the Philippine military reported that Khaddafi's remains had been recovered near Patikul, in Jolo and that DNA tests had been ordered to confirm the discovery. Observers were skeptical about whether the pledge would lead to Abu Sayyaf becoming an ISIS outpost in Southeast Asia, or was simply a way for the group to take advantage of the newer group's international publicity. ==Supporters and funding== Abdurajik Abubakar Janjalani's first recruits were soldiers of MNLF and the [[Moro Islamic Liberation Front]] (MILF). However, both MNLF and MILF deny links with Abu Sayyaf. Both officially distance themselves because of its attacks on civilians and its supposed profiteering. The Philippine military, however, has claimed that elements of both groups provide support to Abu Sayyaf. guerillas such as Abu Sayyaf have been described as "rooted in a distinct class made up of closely knit networks built through marriage of important families through socioeconomic backgrounds and family structures", according to Michael Buehler. This tight-knit, familial structure provides resilience, but also limits their growth. Commander of the Western Mindanao Command Lieutenant General Rustico Guerrero, describes Abu Sayyaf as "a local group with a local agenda". Two kidnapping victims, (Martin and [[Gracia Burnham]]) who were kept in captivity by ASG for over a year, "gently engaged their captors in theological discussion" and found Abu Sayyaf fighters to be unfamiliar with the [[Qur'an]]. They had only "a sketchy" notion of Islam, which they saw as "a set of behavioural rules, to be violated when it suited them", according to author [[Mark Bowden]]. As "[[mujahideen|holy warriors]], they were justified in kidnapping, killing and stealing. Having sex with women captives was justified by their claiming them as "wives".{{cite magazine|author=Bowden, Mark|title=Jihadists in Paradise|url=https://www.theatlantic.com/magazine/archive/2007/03/jihadists-in-paradise/305613/2/|magazine=The Atlantic|date=1 March 2007}} Unlike MILF and MNLF, the group is not recognised by the [[Organisation of Islamic Cooperation]], and according to author [[Robert (Bob) East|Robert East]], was seen as "nothing more than a criminal operation" at least prior to 2001.{{cite book|last1=East|first1=Robert|title=Terror Truncated: The Decline of the Abu Sayyaf Group from the Crucial Year 2002|date=17 May 2015|publisher=Cambridge Scholars Publishing.|page=2|url={{google books |plainurl=y |id=pzgyBwAAQBAJ|page=2}}|accessdate=17 May 2015}} A [[Center for Strategic and International Studies]] report by Jack Fellman notes the political rather than religious motivation of ASG. He quotes Khadaffy's statement that his brother was right to split from MNLF because "up to now, nothing came out" of attempts to gain more autonomy for Moro Muslims. mind of Abu Sayyaf man|author=Philip Golingai|work=The Star|date=1 October 2016|accessdate=3 October 2016}} ===Targets=== Most Abu Sayyaf victims have been Filipinos; however, in recent years (especially from 2011 onwards), Australian, British, Canadian, Chinese, Dutch, French, German, Indonesian, Japanese, Korean, Malaysian, Norwegian, Swiss and Vietnamese nationals have been kidnapped or attacked. Previously, Americans were particularly targeted. An unnamed ASG spokesman allegedly stated, "We have been trying hard to get an American because they may think we are afraid of them". He added, "We want to fight the American people."{{cite web|title=Engine trouble and kidnappings|url=http://www.sailingtotem.com/2014/06/engine-trouble-and-kidnappings.html|website=sailingtotem.com|accessdate=16 May 2015|date=25 June 2014}} In 1993, Abu Sayyaf kidnapped an American Bible translator. In 2000, Abu Sayyaf captured an American Muslim and demanded that the United States release [[Sheikh Omar Abdel Rahman]] and [[Ramzi Yousef]], who were jailed for their involvement in the 1993 [[World Trade Center bombing]] in New York City. Between March 2016 – July 2017, the majority of Abu Sayyaf kidnap for ransom operations shifted to the high seas. Seventeen ships were boarded and some sixty-five hostages from six countries were taken. In total, thirty hostages have been released (usually after a ransom was paid), seven escaped, three were rescued by Philippine security forces, and four were executed. Two others were killed during the attacks while eight seamen escaped during the shipjackings. An additional forty seamen were not taken hostage.{{cite news|url=https://thediplomat.com/2017/08/why-vietnam-must-fight-the-islamic-state-terror-threat/|title=Why Vietnam Must Fight the Islamic State Terror Threat|work=The Diplomat by Zachary Abuza|date=3 August 2017|access-date=19 January 2018}} ==Crimes and terrorism== {{Main|Timeline of Abu Sayyaf attacks}} Abu Sayyaf has carried out numerous [[bombing]]s, [[kidnapping]]s, assassinations, and [[extortion]] activities. These include the [[2000 Sipadan kidnappings]], the 2001 [[Dos Palmas kidnappings]] and the [[2004 SuperFerry 14 bombing]]. ===Kidnappings=== Although the group has engaged in kidnapping hostages to be exchanged for ransom for many years, this means of funding grew dramatically beginning in 2014, providing funds for the group's rapid growth.{{cite news|last1=Hookway|first1=James|title=Terror Grows in Southern Philippines From Militants Linked to Islamic State Kidnappings, beheadings by Abu Sayyaf raise fears of expanding terror threat in Southeast Asia|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/terror-grows-in-southern-philippines-from-militants-linked-to-islamic-state-1479465005|accessdate=20 November 2016|newspaper=[[The Wall Street Journal]]|date=18 November 2016}} ====In the Philippines==== =====Journalists abducted since 2000===== [[ABS–CBN Corporation|ABS-CBN]]'s ''Newsbreak'' reported that Abu Sayyaf abducted at least 20 journalists from 2000 to 2008 (mostly foreign journalists). The two crew were freed in February 2013. [[Al Arabiya]] News Channel stated that their correspondent, Atyani, was handed over to the local governor's office on 4 December 2013.{{cite web|url=http://www.philstar.com/nation/2013/12/05/1264474/updated-abu-sayyaf-releases-jordanian-journalist|title=Abu Sayyaf releases Jordanian journalist|work=The Philippine Star|date=5 December 2013|accessdate=2 February 2018}} However, police and military officials could not ascertain whether Atyani had escaped from his captors or was freed.{{cite web|url=http://www.gmanetwork.com/news/news/nation/338455/jordanian-journalist-atyani-escaped-from-abu-sayyaf-report/story/|title=Jordanian journalist Atyani escaped from Abu Sayyaf —report|publisher=GMA News|date=5 December 2013|accessdate=2 February 2018}} =====Jeffrey Schilling===== On 31 August 2000, American citizen and Muslim convert Jeffrey Schilling from [[Oakland, California]] was captured on [[Jolo]] while visiting a terrorist camp with his new wife, Ivy Osani (a cousin of Abu Sabaya, one of the rebel leaders), whom he had met online. ASG demanded a $10 million ransom. Rebels also sarcastically threatened to behead him in 2001 as a "birthday present" to then Philippine President [[Gloria Macapagal Arroyo]], who responded by declaring "all-out war" on them. The beheading threat was withdrawn after Schilling's mother, Carol, flew to the Philippines and appealed for mercy on local radio. On 12 April 2001, Philippine soldiers raided a rebel camp and rescued the American. The United States praised the Philippine government for freeing Schilling.{{cite news|url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/2001-04-13/news/0104130152_1_abu-sayyaf-ivy-osani-american-hostage-jeffrey-schilling|title=Philippine Soldiers Rescue U.s. Hostage|work=Chicago Tribune|date=13 April 2001|accessdate=4 February 2018}}{{cite news |url=http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2001/04/02/world/main283170.shtml |publisher=CBS News |date=12 April 2001 |title=US Hostage Freed in Philippines}}{{cite news |url=http://edition.cnn.com/TRANSCRIPTS/0207/23/bn.01.html |title=Larry Thompson, Deputy Attorney General (Live Transcript) |date=23 July 2002 |publisher=CNN}} Many commentators have been critical of Schilling, who claims to have walked willingly into the camp after he was invited by his wife's cousin, a member of Abu Sayyaf.{{cite news |url=http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?file=/chronicle/archive/2001/04/14/MNE165246.DTL |title= What Was Schilling Thinking? Oblivious Oakland Man Sets Himself Up |work=San Francisco Chronicle |date=14 April 2001 |author=Chip Johnson}} Schilling was one of more than forty hostages taken by Abu Sayyaf in 2000, including twenty-one tourists and workers seized in a raid on [[Abu Sayyaf#2000 Sipadan kidnappings|Sipadan]] diving resort in neighbouring Malaysia. Many of the hostages were released after Libya paid millions of dollars. A Libyan official stated that Schilling had visited the Jolo camp often before his capture. Philippine intelligence sources say he was interested in selling military equipment to the rebels, while the bandits accused him of being a CIA agent. Abu Sayyaf threatened several times to kill Schilling. At one stage, Schilling reportedly went on a hunger strike to win his freedom. =====Martin and Gracia Burnham===== {{See also|Dos Palmas kidnappings}} On 27 May 2001, an Abu Sayyaf raid kidnapped about 20 people from Dos Palmas, an expensive resort in Honda Bay, taking them to the north of [[Puerto Princesa City]] on the island of [[Palawan]], which had been "considered completely safe". The most "valuable" hostages were three North Americans, Martin and Gracia Burnham, a [[missionary]] couple, and Guillermo Sobero, a Peruvian-American tourist who was later [[Decapitation|beheaded]], following a $1 million [[ransom]] demand.{{cite web|url=http://newsstand.blogs.com/newsstand/2007/01/turns_out_abu_s.html|title=Newsstand: Gracia's enemies|date=6 December 2008|url-status=dead|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081206072229/http://newsstand.blogs.com/newsstand/2007/01/turns_out_abu_s.html|archivedate=6 December 2008}} The hostages and hostage-takers then returned to Abu Sayyaf territories in Mindanao."Manhunt" by Mark Bowden, ''The Atlantic'', March 2007, p.54 (15) According to Bowden, the leader of the raid was Abu Sabaya. According to [[Gracia Burnham]], she told her husband "to identify his kidnappers" to authorities "as 'the Osama bin Laden Group,' but Burnham was unfamiliar with that name and stuck with" Abu Sayyaf. After returning to Mindanao, Abu Sayyaf conducted numerous raids, including one that culminated in the [[Siege of Lamitan]] and "one at a coconut plantation called Golden Harvest; they took about 15 people captive there and later used [[bolo knife|bolo knives]] to hack the heads off two men. The number of hostages waxed and waned as some were ransomed and released, new ones were taken and others were killed." On 7 June 2002, about a year after the raid, Philippine army troops conducted a rescue operation in which Martin Burnham and Filipino nurse Ediborah Yap were killed. The remaining hostage was wounded and the hostage takers escaped. In July 2004, Gracia Burnham [[Testimony|testified]] at a trial of eight Abu Sayyaf members and identified six of the suspects as her captors, including Alhamzer Limbong, Abdul Azan Diamla, Abu Khari Moctar, Bas Ishmael, Alzen Jandul, and Dazid Baize. "The eight suspects sat silently during her three-hour testimony, separated from her by a wooden grill. They face the death sentence if found guilty of kidnapping for ransom. The trial began this year and is not expected to end for several months."{{cite web|url=http://www.graciaburnham.org/pdf/Article_7-30-04.pdf |title=Burham identifies former Abu Captors |accessdate=3 April 2012 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20051203025534/http://www.graciaburnham.org/pdf/Article_7-30-04.pdf |archivedate=3 December 2005 }} Alhamzer Limbong was later killed in a [[Prison riot|prison uprising]]."[http://www.graciaburnham.org/index.asp?sec=3_1 Philippines Brace for Retaliation] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100509081455/http://www.graciaburnham.org/index.asp?sec=3_1 |date=9 May 2010 }}" 15 March 2005, Associated Press. Burnham claimed that Philippine military officials were colluding with her captors, saying that the Armed Forces of the Philippines "didn't pursue us...As time went on, we noticed that they never pursued us".{{cite book|url={{google books |plainurl=y |id=XtE5QEW0ukUC}} |title=In the Presence of My Enemies |accessdate=3 April 2012}} =====2007 Father Bossi kidnapping===== On 10 June 2007, Italian priest Reverend Giancarlo Bossi was kidnapped near [[Pagadian]], capital of [[Zamboanga del Sur]] Province in the southern Philippines. [[Pope Benedict XVI]] made an appeal to free him. Bossi was released on 19 July 2007 at Karumatan, a Muslim town in [[Lanao del Norte]] Province, allegedly after the payment of ransom. Father Bossi died in Italy on 23 September 2012.{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2007/07/20/world/europe/20iht-phils.1.6746806.html|title=Kidnapped Italian priest is freed in Philippines|work=The New York Times|date=20 July 2007|accessdate=4 February 2018}}{{cite news|url=http://www.gmanetwork.com/news/news/nation/275293/italian-priest-giancarlo-bossi-former-kidnap-victim-in-mindanao-dies/story/|title=Italian priest Giancarlo Bossi, former kidnap victim in Mindanao, dies|work=GMA online|date=24 September 2012|accessdate=4 February 2018}} =====2009 Red Cross kidnapping===== On 15 January 2009, Abu Sayyaf kidnapped [[International Committee of the Red Cross]] (ICRC) delegates in [[Patikul, Sulu|Patikul]], Sulu Province, Philippines. Three ICRC workers had finished conducting field work in Sulu province, located in the southwest of the country, when they were abducted by an unknown group, later confirmed as [[Albader Parad]]'s group.{{cite news |first=Julie |last=Alipala |title=3 Red Cross kidnap victims alive, safe |date=17 January 2009 |accessdate=31 March 2009 |url=http://www.inquirer.net/specialreports/redcrossabduction/view.php?db=1&article=20090117-183958 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120829223037/http://www.inquirer.net/specialreports/redcrossabduction/view.php?db=1&article=20090117-183958 |archivedate=29 August 2012 }} All three were eventually released. According to a CNN story, Parad was reportedly killed, along with five other militants, in an assault by Philippine marines in Sulu province on Sunday, 21 February 2010. =====2009 Irish priest kidnapping===== On 11 October 2009, Irish Catholic missionary Michael Sinnott, aged 79, from [[Barntown]] [[County Wexford]] was kidnapped from a gated compound in [[Pagadian]], the capital of [[Zamboanga del Sur]] province, suspected to be part of ASG and some renegade members of MILF. Swiss Lorenzo Vinciguerra escaped in December 2014 as government troops attacked the jungle camp where he was captive on the island of Jolo. Vinciguerra was shot by rebels as he escaped; however, his injuries were non-life-threatening.{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-30358073|title=Swiss hostages escapes Abu Sayyaf captors in Philippines|publisher=BBC News|date=6 December 2014|accessdate=29 January 2018}} Dutch captive Ewold Horn was reportedly 'very sick and very weak' and unable to escape.{{cite web|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2863341/Swiss-photographer-held-hostage-Islamist-extremists-two-years-escapes-grabbing-machete-cutting-captor-s-throat-dramatic-break-freedom.html|title=Swiss photographer held hostage by Islamist extremists for two years escapes by grabbing machete and cutting captor's throat in dramatic break for freedom|publisher=Daily Mail Australia|date=6 December 2014|accessdate=29 January 2018}} The whereabouts of Horn remained unknown.{{cite web|url=https://thediplomat.com/2016/09/philippine-militancy-in-the-spotlight-with-freed-norwegian-hostage/|title=Philippine Militancy in the Spotlight with Freed Norwegian Hostage|publisher=The Diplomat by Luke Hunt |date=20 September 2016|accessdate=29 January 2018}} On 31 May 2019, Western Mindanao Command confirmed that Horn was shot dead during a clash with military in Patikul, Sulu. Additionally, the military advised that the wife of ASG leader Radulan Sahiron and five other ASG members were also killed.{{cite web|url=https://newsinfo.inquirer.net/1125422/kidnapped-dutch-ewold-horn-dead-in-sulu-clash|title=Kidnapped Dutch Ewold Horn dead in Sulu clash|publisher=Inquirer.net Julie Alipala |date=31 May 2019|accessdate=31 May 2019}}{{cite web|url=https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2019/05/dutch-hostage-held-philippines-killed-gun-battle-190531135208985.html|title=Dutch hostage held in Philippines killed in gun battle|publisher=Al Jazeera|date=1 June 2019|accessdate=2 June 2019}} =====2012 Mayor Jeffrey Lim Kidnapping===== On 2 April 2012, Mayor Jeffrey Lim of [[Salug, Zamboanga del Norte]] was kidnapped by ten armed men disguised as policemen. Lim was reportedly handed over to Abu Sayyaf. On 6 November, he was freed near [[Zamboanga City]] after payment of P1.3M ($US25,000) ransom. Gumandol was arrested on 12 June 2016.{{cite web|url=http://www.philstar.com:8080/nation/2016/06/13/1592224/suspect-ex-priests-kidnap-falls|title=Suspect in ex-priest's kidnap falls|work=The Star|date=13 June 2016|accessdate=8 February 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180208064030/http://www.philstar.com:8080/nation/2016/06/13/1592224/suspect-ex-priests-kidnap-falls|archive-date=8 February 2018|url-status=dead}} =====2014 Kabasalan ZSP kidnapping===== On 11 September 2014, Chinese national Li Pei Zhei was abducted by four gunmen in [[Kabasalan, Zamboanga Sibugay]] and taken to Basilan. He was released in Sitio Lugay-Lugay, Barangay Naga-Naga, [[Alicia, Zamboanga Sibugay]] on 5 November 2014.{{cite web|url=http://pro9.pnp.gov.ph/index.php/public-relations/news-release/485-chinese-kidnap-victim-freed-in-sibugay|title=CHINESE KIDNAP VICTIM FREED IN SIBUGAY|publisher=Philippine National Police|date=6 November 2014|accessdate=2 February 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180202193243/http://pro9.pnp.gov.ph/index.php/public-relations/news-release/485-chinese-kidnap-victim-freed-in-sibugay|archive-date=2 February 2018|url-status=dead}} Police subsequently charged Ibni Basaludin, Yug Enriquez, Brahama Ali, and Ging-Ging Calon, all residents of Barangay Tenan, [[Ipil, Zamboanga Sibugay]] with kidnapping with serious illegal detention.{{cite web|url=http://www.mindanews.com/top-stories/2014/11/4-charged-for-chinese-businessmans-kidnap-in-zambo-sibugay/|title=4 charged for Chinese businessman's kidnap in Zambo Sibugay|publisher=MindaNews|date=7 November 2014|accessdate=2 February 2018}} =====2015 Roseller Lim ZSP kidnapping===== On 24 January 2015, Korean national Nwi Seong Hong was abducted by armed men in [[Roseller Lim, Zamboanga Sibugay]] Province. The victim's son, Abby, escaped after he fought off the kidnappers.{{cite news|url= http://www.philstar.com/headlines/2015/11/02/1517439/kidnapped-korean-found-dead-sulu|title=Kidnapped Korean found dead in Sulu|work=The Philippine Star|accessdate=30 January 2018|date=2 November 2015}} According to intelligence information from the JTG-SULU, the captors of were Algabsy Misaya, Idang Susukan, Alden Bagade and Mohammad Salud alias Ama Maas, Indanan-based members led by sub-leaders Isang Susukan and Anga Adji.{{cite web|url=http://philexaminer.com/?p=2089|title=Korean kidnap victim found dead in Jolo |work=The Philippine Examiner|date=November 2015|access-date=18 November 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151119022108/http://philexaminer.com/?p=2089|archive-date=19 November 2015|url-status=dead}}{{cite news|url= https://www.rappler.com/nation/111350-korean-victim-nwi-seong-hong-found-dead|title=Korean kidnap victim found dead in Sulu|work=Rappler|accessdate=30 January 2018|date=1 November 2015}} On 31 October 2015, the body of 74-year-old Nwi Seong Hong was found in Barangay Bangkal, [[Patikul, Sulu]]. Abu Rami, an ASG spokesman, claimed $638,000 was paid as ransom.{{cite web|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/2016/09/abu-sayyaf-frees-norwegian-hostage-kjartan-sekkingstad-160917112112583.html|title=Abu Sayyaf frees Norwegian hostage Kjartan Sekkingstad|publisher=Al Jazeera|accessdate=19 September 2016}} =====2015 Dipolog City kidnapping===== On 7 October 2015, Italian national and pizza restaurant owner Rolando del Torchio was kidnapped in [[Dipolog]] City, capital of [[Zamboanga del Norte]] Province. On 8 April 2016, Del Torchio was released and found at [[Jolo]] port aboard MV KC Beatrice bound for [[Zamboanga City]] after his family paid P29 million ($US650,000) in ransom.{{cite news|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2016-04-09/former-italian-priest-freed-by-aby-sayaf-militants/7313488|title=Abu Sayaf militants release former Italian priest Rolando Del Torchio from captivity in Philippines|work=ABC News Australia|date=9 April 2016|accessdate=4 February 2018}} ====2019 Takuran kidnapping==== On 4 October 2019, armed men abducted British national Allan Hyrons and his Filipino wife Wilma from their beach resort in Takuran town, Zamboanga del Sur province on the southern island of Mindanao. After a brief exchange of gunfire in November between Abu Sayyaf and Philippine troops on the island of Jolo, the couple were abandoned and rescued. No ransom was reportedly paid.{{cite news|url=https://www.abc.net.au/news/2019-11-25/philippine-troops-rescue-couple-kidnapped-by-abu-sayyaf/11736814|title=Philippine troops rescue couple kidnapped by IS-linked jihadists Abu Sayyaf in running firefight|work=ABC News Australia|date=25 November 2019|accessdate=25 November 2019}}{{cite news|url=https://cnnphilippines.com/regional/2019/11/25/British-national-Filipino-wife-rescued-Hyrons.html|title=Military rescues abducted British national, Filipino wife from Abu Sayyaf|publisher=CNN|date=25 November 2019|accessdate=26 November 2019}} ====In Malaysia==== {{See also|Cross border attacks in Sabah}} =====2000 Sipadan kidnappings===== {{Main|2000 Sipadan kidnappings}} On 3 May 2000, Abu Sayyaf guerillas occupied the Malaysian dive resort island [[Sipadan]] and took 21 [[hostage]]s, including 10 tourists and 11 resort workers – 19 foreign nationals in total. The hostages were taken to an Abu Sayyaf base in [[Jolo]].{{cite news | title= Abu Sayyaf kidnappings, bombings and other attacks | url= http://www.gmanews.tv/story/154797/abu-sayyaf-kidnappings-bombings-and-other-attacks | work= GMA News | date= 23 August 2007 | accessdate =22 March 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100422202244/http://www.gmanews.tv/story/154797/abu-sayyaf-kidnappings-bombings-and-other-attacks| archivedate= 22 April 2010 | url-status= live}} Two Muslim Malaysians were released soon after. Abu Sayyaf made various demands for the release of several prisoners, including [[1993 World Trade Center bombing|1993 World Trade Center bomber]] [[Ramzi Yousef]] and $2.4 million. In July, a Filipino television evangelist and 12 of members of the [[Jesus Miracle Crusade]] Church offered their help and went as mediators for the relief of other hostages.{{cite web|url=http://jmcim.org|title=jmcim.org|accessdate=13 November 2014}} They, three French television crew members and a German journalist, all visiting Abu Sayyaf on Jolo, were also taken hostage.{{cite news|author=Freeman Washington|url=http://www.cdnn.info/news/industry/i000910.html|title=Abu Sayyaf Muslim rebels raped Sipadan dive tourist hostages| newspaper=cdnn.info |date=10 September 2000 |accessdate=23 March 2010}} Most hostages were released in August and September 2000, partly due to mediation by Libyan leader [[Muammar Gaddafi]] and an offer of $25 million in "development aid".{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/asia-pacific/898190.stm |title=BBC news.uk |publisher=BBC News |date=28 August 2000 |accessdate=3 April 2012}} Abu Sayyaf conducted a second raid on the island of Pandanan near Sipadan on 10 September and seized three more Malaysians.{{cite web|url=http://www.cdnn.info/special-report/sipadan/sipadan_timeline.html |title=Sipadan Timeline |publisher=cdnn.info |accessdate=3 April 2012}} The Philippine army launched a major offensive on 16 September 2000, rescuing all remaining hostages, except Filipino dive instructor Roland Ullah. He was freed in 2003. Abu Sayyaf coordinated with the Chinese [[14K Triad]] gang in carrying out the kidnappings. The 14K Triad has militarily supported Abu Sayyaf. =====2013 Pom Pom kidnappings===== On 15 November 2013, Abu Sayyaf militants raided a [[resort]] on the Malaysian island of [[Pom Pom Island|Pom Pom]].{{cite web|url=http://www.emirates247.com/news/pom-pom-island-tourist-killed-wife-kidnapped-2013-11-16-1.528227|title=Pom Pom Island: Tourist killed, wife kidnapped|publisher=[[Emirates 24/7]]|date=16 November 2013|accessdate=6 April 2014}}{{cite web|url=http://www.wantchinatimes.com/news-subclass-cnt.aspx?id=20131222000063&cid=1101 |title=Militant group Abu Sayyaf behind Taiwanese woman's kidnapping |work=Want China Times |date=22 December 2013 |accessdate=6 April 2014 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141031041945/http://www.wantchinatimes.com/news-subclass-cnt.aspx?id=20131222000063&cid=1101 |archivedate=31 October 2014 }} During the ambush, Taiwanese citizen Chang An-wei was kidnapped and her husband, Hsu Li-min, was killed.{{cite web |url=http://focustaiwan.tw/news/asoc/201312230032.aspx |publisher=Focus Taiwan |title=Kidnapping victim thanks helper for securing release |accessdate=7 June 2014}} Chang was taken to the [[Sulu Archipelago]]. I will follow you"|agency=Bernama|work=The Star|date=16 June 2014|accessdate=17 June 2014}} The worker managed to escape and disappeared.{{cite web|url=http://www.straitstimes.com/news/asia/south-east-asia/story/fish-farm-worker-manages-escape-armed-kidnappers-sabah-20140616|title=Fish farm worker manages to escape armed kidnappers in Sabah|work=The Star/[[Asia News Network]]|date=16 June 2014|accessdate=17 June 2014}}{{cite news|url=http://www.dailyexpress.com.my/news.cfm?NewsID=90074|title=Hostage who escaped sought|newspaper=Daily Express|date=18 June 2014|accessdate=21 June 2014}} Meanwhile, the fish farm manager was taken to Jolo.{{cite web|url=http://www.thestar.com.my/News/Nation/2014/06/20/Kidnappers-contact-fish-breeders-wife-No-ransom-demand-was-made/|title=Kidnappers contact fish breeder's wife|work=The Star|date=20 June 2014|accessdate=21 June 2014}} He was released on 10 December.{{cite web|url=http://www.thesundaily.my/news/1264262|title=Fish breeder released by Abu Sayyaf|work=The Sun|date=10 December 2014|accessdate=11 December 2014}} Malaysian authorities identified five Filipinos, the "Muktadil brothers", as responsible for these cases. His body was discovered in a pump boat in Mususiasi.{{cite web|url=http://www.thestar.com.my/news/nation/2016/09/30/last-of-muktadil-brothers-killed-badong-found-dead-after-military-shootout/|title=Last of Muktadil brothers killed|author=Muguntan Vanar|work=The Star|date=30 September 2016|accessdate=3 October 2016}} =====2015 Ocean King Restaurant kidnappings===== On 15 May 2015, four armed Abu Sayyaf members kidnapped two Malaysian nationals from Ocean King Restaurant in an upscale resort in [[Sandakan]], Sabah and took them to [[Parang, Sulu]].{{cite news|url=http://www.theborneopost.com/2015/05/16/kidnapping-incident-in-sabah-recurs/|title=Kidnapping incident in Sabah recurs|newspaper=Borneo Post|date=16 May 2015|accessdate=16 May 2015}}{{cite web|url=http://www.gmanetwork.com/news/story/487930/news/regions/police-abu-sayyaf-linked-to-sabah-kidnap|title=Police: Abu Sayyaf linked to Sabah kidnap|publisher=GMA News|date=15 May 2015|accessdate=16 May 2015}} Police identified the leaders of the group behind the abduction as Alhabsy Misaya, Alden Bagade and Angah Adji. On 8 November, Thien Nyuk Fun, the seafood restaurant owner, was released after payment of 30 million pesos ($US675,000) ransom.{{cite web|url=http://globalnation.inquirer.net/130670/sabah-hostage-released-by-abu-sayyaf-gunmen|title=Sabah hostage released by Abu Sayyaf gunmen|work=The Star/Asia News Network|date=9 November 2015|accessdate=9 November 2015}}{{cite news|url=http://www.straitstimes.com/asia/se-asia/abu-sayyaf-releases-thien-nyuk-fun-one-of-two-malaysians-taken-from-sabah-restaurant|title=Abu Sayyaf releases Thien Nyuk Fun, one of two Malaysians taken from Sabah restaurant|work=The Straits Times|date=9 November 2015|accessdate=5 February 2018}} The initial agreement of 30 million pesos was reportedly for both hostages; however, a faction within the Abu Sayyaf Group demanded more after Thien Nyuk Fun was released. Further negotiations broke down and the other hostage, electrical engineer Bernard Then, was beheaded on Jolo Island on 17 November.{{cite web|url=http://www.thestar.com.my/News/Nation/2015/11/17/Bernard-then-killed-abu-sayyaf/|title=Malaysian hostage Bernard Then beheaded|author1=Muguntan Vanar|author2=Stephanie Lee|work=The Star|date=17 November 2015|accessdate=18 November 2015}}{{cite web|url=http://www.thestar.com.my/News/Nation/2015/11/17/Bernard-Then-beheading-ransom-not-met/|title=Demand for higher ransom led to beheading|work=The Star|date=17 November 2015|accessdate=18 November 2015}}{{cite news|url=https://www.thestar.com.my/news/nation/2015/11/17/bernard-then-killed-abu-sayyaf/|title=Malaysian hostage Bernard Then beheaded|work=The Star|date=17 November 2015|accessdate=5 February 2018}}{{cite news|url=https://www.thestar.com.my/opinion/columnists/one-mans-meat/2015/11/21/why-bernard-then-was-beheaded/|title=Why Bernard Then was beheaded|work=The Star|date=21 November 2015|accessdate=5 February 2018}} ====Philippines and Malaysia waters==== =====2014 German sailors kidnapping===== In April 2014, Germans Dr. Stefan Viktor Okonek and Henrike Dielen were captured on their yacht on the high seas near Borneo. Abu Sayyaf threatened to behead one of them. After payment of $US5.6 million in October 2014, the pair were released in Patikul, Sulu.{{Cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-philippines-militants/philippine-militants-free-two-german-hostages-idUSKCN0I607S20141017|title=Philippine militants free two German hostages|agency=Reuters|date=17 October 2014|accessdate=29 January 2018}} =====2016 Local and foreign sailors kidnappings===== On 26 March 2016, ten Indonesian seafarers were held hostage by ASG operating in [[Sulu Archipelago]]. They were abducted from the Brahma 12 tugboat and the Anand 12 barge{{Cite news|url=http://www.marinelink.com/news/indonesian-hostages408407.aspx|title=Ship Owner to Pay Ransom for Indonesian Hostages|date=20 April 2016|work=MarineLink|access-date=29 January 2018}} near [[Tawi-Tawi province]].{{cite news | title = 10 Indonesian sailors kidnapped in the Philippines | author = Ray Sanchez | publisher = CNN | date = 29 March 2016 | url = http://edition.cnn.com/2016/03/29/asia/philippines-indonesia-sailors-hostage/}} The Indonesian vessels were freighting coal from [[South Borneo]] heading for [[Batangas]] port when hijacked. In April, the Indonesian government announced that the company that owned tugboat ''Brahma 12'' had agreed to pay the 50-million-peso ($1 million) ransom.{{cite news | title = Ship Owner to Pay Ransom for Indonesian Hostages | author = Aiswarya Lakshmi | work = MarineLink.com | date = 20 April 2016 | url = http://www.marinelink.com/news/indonesian-hostages408407.aspx}} On 2 May, they were released.{{cite news | title = 10 Indonesian hostages released by Islamist militant group, president says | author = Tim Hume and Kathy Quiano | publisher = CNN | date = 2 May 2016 | url = http://edition.cnn.com/2016/05/01/asia/indonesia-philippines-abu-sayyaf-hostages/}} On 1 April, four [[Malaysians|Malaysian]] sailors aboard a tugboat from Manila were kidnapped when they arrived near the shore of [[Ligitan Island]]. Their companions, three Myanmar nationals and two Indonesians, were unharmed.{{cite news|url=http://www.theborneopost.com/2016/04/03/four-sarawakians-kidnapped/|title=Four Sarawakians kidnapped|author1=Nancy Lai|author2=Margaret Ringgit|newspaper=Borneo Post|date=3 April 2016|accessdate=3 April 2016}} On 8 June, they were released.{{cite web|url=http://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/asiapacific/4-malaysians-released-by/2854376.html|title=4 Malaysians released by Abu Sayyaf: Philippine military|publisher=Channel NewsAsia|date=8 June 2016|accessdate=15 June 2016}} On 15 April, four Indonesian sailors were kidnapped when two Indonesian tugboats from [[Cebu]], ''Henry'' and ''Cristi'', were attacked by Abu Sayyaf militants. While five of the passengers were safe, one was shot before he was rescued.{{cite web|url=http://news.okezone.com/read/2016/04/16/337/1364473/kapal-indonesia-kembali-dibajak-4-wni-diculik-1-ditembak|title=Kapal Indonesia Kembali Dibajak, 4 WNI Diculik & 1 Ditembak|author=Arief Setyadi|language=Indonesian|publisher=Okezone|date=16 April 2016|accessdate=16 April 2016}} They were released on 11 May.{{cite news|url=http://www.thejakartapost.com/news/2016/05/12/abu-sayyaf-releases-four-remaining-ri-hostages.html|title=Abu Sayyaf releases four remaining RI hostages|author1=Ina Parlina|author2=Tama Salim|newspaper=The Jakarta Post|date=12 May 2016|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160513122712/http://www.thejakartapost.com/news/2016/05/12/abu-sayyaf-releases-four-remaining-ri-hostages.html|archivedate=13 May 2016|url-status=dead}} A group of concerned Filipinos in Sabah urged Philippine president-elect [[Rodrigo Duterte]] to intervene for the release of four Malaysians held hostage by Abu Sayyaf. The issue strained the relationship between the Philippines and Malaysia.{{cite news|url=http://www.dailyexpress.com.my/news.cfm?NewsID=109710|title=Filipinos in Sabah urge Duterte: Help free hostages|newspaper=Daily Express|date=13 May 2016|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160513123353/http://www.dailyexpress.com.my/news.cfm?NewsID=109710|archivedate=13 May 2016|url-status=dead}} On 21 June, seven Indonesian sailors were kidnapped while aboard a tugboat passing through the Sulu Archipelago.{{cite news|url=http://newsinfo.inquirer.net/792201/abu-kidnappers-seize-7-indonesians|title=Abu kidnappers seize 7 Indonesians|author=Estrella Torres|newspaper=Philippine Daily Inquirer|date=24 June 2016|accessdate=10 July 2016}} On 9 July, three Indonesian fishermen were kidnapped near the coast of Lahad Datu, Sabah, Malaysia{{cite news|url=http://jakartaglobe.beritasatu.com/news/armed-men-kidnap-three-indonesians-off-sabah-coast/|title=Armed Men Kidnap Three Indonesians Off Sabah Coast|newspaper=Jakarta Globe|date=10 July 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161016234539/http://jakartaglobe.beritasatu.com/news/armed-men-kidnap-three-indonesians-off-sabah-coast|archive-date=16 October 2016|url-status=dead}} and released on 17 September.{{cite web|url=http://www.nst.com.my/news/2016/09/174118/three-indonesians-abducted-sabah-waters-freed-militant-abu-sayyaf-group?|title=Three Indonesians abducted in Sabah waters freed by militant Abu Sayyaf group|agency=Reuters|work=New Straits Times|date=18 September 2016|accessdate=18 September 2016}} On 18 July, five Malaysian sailors were abducted near the coast of Lahad Datu.{{cite web|url=http://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/asiapacific/5-malaysian-crewmen/2969950.html|title=5 Malaysian crewmen kidnapped by Abu Sayyaf: Philippine official|publisher=Channel NewsAsia|date=20 July 2016|accessdate=26 July 2016}} On 3 August, an Indonesian sailor was kidnapped in the waters of Malaysia leaving two other crew members unharmed. This incident was reported by victims on 5 August.{{cite web|url=http://www.antaranews.com/en/news/106126/govt-confirms-one-more-indonesian-abducted-in-malaysian-water|title=Govt confirms one more Indonesian abducted in Malaysian water|author=Heru|publisher=Antara|date=7 August 2016|accessdate=11 August 2016}} Two of the hostages managed to escape after receiving persistent threats of beheading.{{cite web|url=http://www.ctvnews.ca/mobile/world/second-indonesian-sailor-manages-to-escape-abu-sayyaf-captors-1.3033492|title=Second Indonesian sailor manages to escape Abu Sayyaf captors|author=Teresa Cerojano|agency=Associated Press|publisher=CTV News|date=18 August 2016|accessdate=4 September 2016}} On 10 September, three Filipino fishermen were kidnapped on the shores of Pom Pom Island.{{cite web|url=http://www.ibtimes.sg/filipino-militants-kidnap-three-fishermen-sabah-waters-3217|title=Filipino militants kidnap three fishermen in Sabah waters|author=Samhati Bhattacharjya|website=International Business Times|date=11 September 2016|accessdate=12 September 2016}}{{cite web|url=http://m.thesundaily.my/node/393969|title=Gunmen kidnaps 3 Filipino fishermen near Pulau Pom Pom|author=Charles Ramendran|work=The Sun|date=11 September 2016|accessdate=12 September 2016}}{{Dead link|date=May 2019 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} On 22 September, another Indonesian hostage was released.{{cite web|url=http://www.rappler.com/world/regions/asia-pacific/indonesia/bahasa/englishedition/147049-abu-sayyaf-hostage-release|title=Another Indonesian hostage released by the Abu Sayyaf|author1=Carmela Fonbuena|author2=Natashya Gutierrez|agency=Agence France-Presse|publisher=Rappler|date=22 September 2016|accessdate=25 September 2016}} On 27 September, one Malaysian boat-skipper was kidnapped from his trawler by seven armed militants before the group attacked another Indonesian trawler; however, no kidnappings were committed in the second incident.{{cite news|url=http://m.themalaymailonline.com/malaysia/article/police-believe-filipino-group-raided-sabah-twice-in-same-night|title=Police believe Filipino group raided Sabah twice in same night|newspaper=The Malay Mail|date=28 September 2016|accessdate=28 September 2016}} The hostage was released on 1 October, with no ransom demand,{{cite web|url=http://www.thestar.com.my/news/nation/2016/10/01/pulau-gaya-kidnap-victim-freed/|title=Fishing boat owner freed by Filipino abductors|author=Muguntan Vanar|work=The Star|date=1 October 2016|accessdate=2 October 2016}} along with three Indonesians hostages who were released the same day.{{cite web|url=http://www.japantimes.co.jp/news/2016/10/03/asia-pacific/abu-sayyaf-frees-indonesia-tugboat-trio-three-months-captivity/|title=Abu Sayyaf frees Indonesia tugboat trio after three months in captivity|agency=Associated Press|work=Japan Times|date=3 October 2016|accessdate=2 October 2016}} On 21 October, approximately ten Abu Sayyaf militants attacked a South Korean-bound vessel named ''MV Dongbang Gian'' and abducted a South Korean skipper and a Filipino crewman off [[Bongao, Tawi-Tawi]].{{cite web|url=http://www.foxnews.com/world/2016/10/21/abu-sayyaf-attacks-s-korean-ship-abducts-skipper-crewman.html|title=Abu Sayyaf attacks S. Korean ship, abducts skipper, crewman|agency=Associated Press|publisher=Fox News Channel|date=21 October 2016|accessdate=23 October 2016}} On 5 November, German sailor Sabine Merz was shot dead while her husband [[Jürgen Kantner]] was abducted from their yacht off Tanjong Luuk Pisuk in Sabah. On or before 27 February 2017, Kantner was beheaded after a ransom of 30 million pesos ($US600,000) was not paid.{{cite news|url=http://www.nst.com.my/news/2016/11/186536/report-german-kidnapped-girlfriend-killed-abu-sayyaf-storm-yacht-sabah-waters|title=Report: German kidnapped, girlfriend killed as Abu Sayyaf storm yacht off Sabah waters|author=Awang Ali Omar|newspaper=New Straits Times|date=7 November 2016|accessdate=7 November 2016}}{{cite web|url=http://www.gmanetwork.com/news/story/587769/news/regions/asg-claims-abducting-german-off-sabah|title=[Female companion found dead in Sulu] ASG claims abducting German off Sabah|publisher=GMA News|date=7 November 2016|accessdate=7 November 2016}}{{cite web|url=https://www.thelocal.de/20170227/german-hostage-beheaded-by-philippine-islamists|title=German sailor beheaded by Philippine Islamists|publisher=GMA News|date=27 February 2017|accessdate=29 January 2018}} On 11 November, Vietnamese vessel MV Royale 16 with nineteen sailors on board was attacked by Abu Sayyaf near Basilan, abducting six sailors and injuring one. The remaining thirteen sailors were released.{{cite web|url=http://tuoitrenews.vn/society/37957/6-vietnamese-abducted-in-attack-on-cargo-ship-off-philippines|title=6 Vietnamese abducted in attack on cargo ship off Philippines|publisher=Tuổi Trẻ|date=11 November 2016|accessdate=7 November 2016}} On 20 November, two Indonesian fishermen were kidnapped by five gunmen off Lahad Datu.{{cite web|url=http://www.thestar.com.my/news/world/2016/11/20/philippines-tries-to-intercept-bandits-as-more-indonesians-snatched-at-sea/|title=Philippines tries to intercept bandits as more fishermen =https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/asia_pacific/apnewsbreak-abu-sayyaf-got-7-million-from-kidnappings/2016/10/27/2e93a898-9c19-11e6-b552-b1f85e484086_story.html | accessdate = 27 October 2016}} ===Beheadings=== {{Main|Abu Sayyaf beheading incidents}} As part of its [[kidnapping|kidnap-for-ransom operations]], the Abu Sayyaf has executed some of their male hostages if ransom demands were not met.{{Cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2016/05/20/how-abu-sayyaf-the-islamist-terror-gang-made-a-business-out-of-b/|title=How Abu Sayyaf makes a business of beheadings as Islamist terror gang releases 'final message' hostage video|author=Philip Sherwell|newspaper=The Telegraph|date=23 May 2016|accessdate=30 July 2016}} The group had previously beheaded Christian civilians and others they consider [[kafir]] without demanding ransoms for their release, due to their religious affiliation.{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/asia/philippines/1336482/Philippines-rebel-kidnappers-behead-nine-Christian-hostages.html|title=Philippines rebel kidnappers behead nine Christian hostages|author=Alex Spillius|newspaper=The Telegraph|date=5 August 2001|accessdate=29 July 2016}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2002/aug/22/alqaida.terrorism|title=Jehovah's Witnesses beheaded in Philippines|newspaper=The Guardian|date=22 August 2002|accessdate=29 July 2016}} ===Bombings=== ====2004 Superferry 14 Bombing==== {{Main|Superferry 14}} [[Superferry 14]] was a large ferry destroyed by a bomb on 27 February 2004, killing 116 people in the [[Philippines]]' worst terrorist attack and the world's deadliest terrorist attack at sea.{{cite web|last=Rommel C. Banlaoi |title=Maritime Terrorism in Southeast Asia: The Abu Sayyaf Threat |url=http://www.usnwc.edu/getattachment/f54ece77-3d67-4c32-bfaa-02b476a569d8/Maritime-Terrorism-in-Southeast-Asia--The-Abu-Sayy|url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110920113008/http://www.usnwc.edu/getattachment/f54ece77-3d67-4c32-bfaa-02b476a569d8/Maritime-Terrorism-in-Southeast-Asia--The-Abu-Sayy |archivedate=20 September 2011 }} On that day, the 10,192 [[ton]] ferry sailed out of [[Manila]] with about 900 passengers and crew on board. A television set filled with 8 lb. (4 kilograms) of [[Trinitrotoluene|TNT]] had been placed on board. 90 minutes out of port, the bomb exploded. 63 people were killed instantly and 53 were missing and presumed dead. Despite claims from terrorist groups, the blast was initially thought to have been an accident caused by a gas explosion. However, after divers righted the ferry five months after it had sunk, they found evidence of a bomb blast. A man called Redendo Cain Dellosa admitted to planting the bomb for Abu Sayyaf.{{cite web|last=Rommel C. Banlaoi|title=Abu Sayyaf Group: Threat of Maritime Piracy and Terrorism|url=http://www.ppl.nl/plinklet/?sid=bibliographies&ppn=302372067&genre=bookitem&issn=&isbn=0415953200&title=The%20Abu%20Sayyaf%20Group%20:%20Threat%20of%20Maritime%20Piracy%20and%20Terrorism%20/%20Rommel%20C.%20Banlaoi&aulast=Banlaoi&aufirst=Rommel%20C.&au2last=&au2first=&au3last=&au3first=&edlast=&edfirst=&ed2last=&ed2first=&ed3last=&ed3first=&source=Violence%20at%20Sea%20:%20Piracy%20in%20the%20Age%20of%20Global%20Terrorism%20/%20ed.%20by%20Peter%20Lehr&year=2007&volume=&issue=&spage=121-137&bibliography=terrorism&table=terrorism&download=N&scharnier=&extensie=&id=14903&url=}} Six suspects were arrested in connection with the bombing while the masterminds, [[Khadaffy Janjalani]] and [[Abu Sulaiman]], were killed.{{cite book|last=Banlaoi|first=Rommel|title=Philippine Security in the Age of Terror|year=2010|publisher=CRC Press Taylor and Francis|location=New York and London|isbn=978-1-4398-1550-2|pages=1–358}} ====2016 Davao City bombing==== {{Main|2016 Davao City bombing}} On 2 September 2016, an explosion occurred at a night market in [[Davao City]], Philippines killing at least 15 and injuring 70.{{cite news|url=http://newsinfo.inquirer.net/813881/davao-blast-suspect-identified-bato-says|title=Davao blast suspect identified, Bato says|author=Julliane Love de Jesus|newspaper=Philippine Daily Inquirer|date=8 September 2016|accessdate=8 September 2016|quote=Victims: 40 died and 70 injured.}}{{cite web|url=http://cnnphilippines.com/news/2016/09/13/pregnant-davao-bombing-victim-dies-in-hospital-death-toll-rises-15.html|title=Pregnant Davao bombing victim dies in hospital; death toll rises to 15|author=Ben O. Tesiorna|publisher=CNN|date=13 September 2016|accessdate=13 September 2016}} Shortly before the bombing, Abu Sayyaf made a threat following the intensified military operation against them.{{cite news|url=http://www.smh.com.au/world/philippines-rodrigo-duterte-issues-wipe-out-order-against-abu-sayyaf-20160831-gr59dw.html|title=Philippines President Rodrigo Duterte issues 'wipe out' order against Abu Sayyaf|author=Lindsay Murdoch|newspaper=The Sydney Morning Herald|date=31 August 2016|accessdate=4 September 2016}}{{cite web|url=http://cnnphilippines.com/news/2016/09/02/AFP-vs-Abu-Sayyaf.html|title=AFP taps 7,000-strong force vs. Abu Sayyaf|author=Eimor P. Santos|publisher=CNN|date=2 September 2016|accessdate=4 September 2016}}{{cite news|url=http://newsinfo.inquirer.net/811993/abu-sayyaf-to-bring-fight-to-afp-doorstep|title=Abu Sayyaf to bring fight to AFP doorstep|author=Julie Alipala|newspaper=Philippine Daily Inquirer|date=2 September 2016|accessdate=4 September 2016}}{{cite news|url=http://newsinfo.inquirer.net/812066/army-pours-troops-into-pursuit-abus-ready-for-last-war|title=Army pours troops into pursuit; Abus ready for 'last war'|author1=Cynthia D. Balana|author2=Julie Alipala|newspaper=Philippine Daily Inquirer|date=2 September 2016|accessdate=4 September 2016}} Abu Sayyaf spokesperson Abu Rami was reported to claim responsibility.{{cite news|url=http://www.rappler.com/nation/145045-abu-sayyaf-responsibility-davao-explosion|title=Abu Sayyaf claims responsibility for Davao blast – report|work=Rappler|date=3 September 2016|accessdate=4 September 2016}} He later denied the report and any involvement, saying a group allied to them; the Daulat Ul-Islamiya were responsible.{{cite news|url=http://newsinfo.inquirer.net/812451/abu-sayyaf-disowns-davao-explosion-says-ally-was-behind-attack|title=Abu Sayyaf disowns Davao explosion, says ally was behind attack|author1=Allan Nawal|author2=Julie Alipala|author3=Karlos Manlupig|newspaper=Philippine Daily Inquirer|date=2 September 2016|accessdate=4 September 2016}} Although the Abu Sayyaf spokesman denied involvement, the Philippine government blame the group. {{quote|This is not the first time that Davao has been sacrificed to the altar of violence. It's always connected with Abu Sayyaf before. They gave a warning. We know that.{{cite web|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/2016/09/philippines-abu-sayyaf-blamed-attack-davao-city-160903025801696.html|title=Philippines: Abu Sayyaf blamed for attack in Davao City|publisher=Al Jazeera|date=3 September 2016|accessdate=4 September 2016}}|[[Rodrigo Duterte]], President of the Philippines}} ====2019 Jolo Cathedral bombings==== {{Main|2019 Jolo Cathedral bombings}} On 27 January 2019, two bombs detonated at the Roman Catholic [[Our Lady of Mount Carmel Cathedral, Jolo|Cathedral of Our Lady of Mount Carmel]] in Jolo town which is the centre of Abu Sayyaf stronghold. The bombings resulting to eighteen people were killed while 82 others were injured, mostly from Philippine Army's [[1st Infantry Division (Philippines)|35th Battalion]] and civilians inside the
